Examination of key factors determining the catalytic performance of Zn-Ga/HZSM-5 bifunctional catalysts and establishment of reaction network in alkylation of benzene with carbon dioxide Yitao Zhao Investigation Data curation Visualization Writing – original draft Methodology, Formal analysi, Investigation, Data curation, Visualization, Writing – original draft Junjun Cheng Methodology, Data curation Peng Zhang Software, Investigation Xinhui Liu Investigation, Visualization Jianguo Zhuang Methodology, Formal analysis Yijun Yu Data curation, Visualization Qichao Zhao Yuchen Wang Xuedong Zhu Visualization, Supervision, Project administration, Funding acquisition, Writing – review & editing ⁎ Fan Yang Methodology, Supervision, Writing – review & editing, Visualization ⁎ Engineering Research Center of Large Scale Reactor Engineering and Technology, Ministry of Education, East China University of Science & Technology, Shanghai 200237, PR China Engineering Research Center of Large Scale Reactor Engineering and Technology, Ministry of Education, East China University of Science & Technology Shanghai 200237 PR China Engineering Research Center of Large Scale Reactor Engineering and Technology, Ministry of Education, East China University of Science & Technology, Shanghai 200237, P. R. China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Alkylation of benzene with carbon dioxide (CO2) is significant for converting greenhouse gas and surplus benzene into value-added toluene and xylene. Herein, a bifunctional catalyst comprising Zn/Ga oxides and HZSM-5 zeolite was developed to efficiently promote the methylation of benzene with CO2 and H2. This catalytic system exhibited excellent performance at 425 ℃ and 3.0 MPa, through which benzene conversion of 39.1% and total xylene/toluene selectivity of 92.7% have been achieved. Furthermore, the catalysts are carefully characterized; compositions of Zn/Ga oxides and Si/Al ratios of HZSM-5 zeolite are recognized as decisive factors for reaction activity and selectivity respectively. Additionally, primary reaction pathways are explored and testified to provide detailed understanding for the establishment of reaction networks, especially for mechanisms of ethylbenzene evolution. These findings are able to provide more deep insights into the process of benzene alkylation, which further facilitates the emergence of effective catalysts with potential industrial applications. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Benzene CO2 hydrogenation Alkylation Bifunctional catalysts Reaction network Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction As important chemical intermediates for the production of fine chemicals, toluene and xylene have extensive industrial applications [1–3]. To name but a few, toluene can be used as solvent, precursors of dyes/rubbers and fuel additives [4], meanwhile xylene is a main intermediate to produce fibers, coatings, plastics and polyesters [5–7]. Recently, a series of ever stricter vehicle emission standards have been implemented worldwide, resulting in excess capacity of benzene production and a sharp drop in benzene price [8]. Thus, converting benzene to toluene and xylene is expected to increase the added value of it. At present, this process can be realized employing methanol [9,10], methane [11] and even syngas as methylation agents [12,13], yet, many researchers are still focusing on exploring more efficient methods. On the other side, the utilization of carbon dioxide (CO2) is of great significance owing to the dramatic climate changes provoked by the ever-increasing emission of CO2, meanwhile the shortages of crude oil is also pressing people to find more alternatives as carbon resources to synthesize daily-chemicals [14]. Catalytic transformation of carbon dioxide into methanol [15], DME [16], light olefins [17] and aromatics [18], would mitigate the above mentioned problems. Given the current situations, the aforementioned issues pertaining to benzene market and greenhouse effects can be mitigated simultaneously if CO2 was able to be utilized directly for benzene methylation. Meanwhile, compared with other toluene/xylene production or CO2 conversion methods, this route is more succinct and of great industrial value. Hence, several works have been carried out in this filed. Briefly, alkylation of benzene with CO2 and H2 (ABCH reaction) is achieved on bifunctional catalysts, over which CO2 and H2 are firstly transformed into methanol via metal/metal oxide, then methanol reacted with benzene to produce toluene/xylene on zeolites [19], wherein oxygen vacancies (OVs) and acid sites are recognized as major active centers, respectively. TiO2 supported Re [20], TiO2 supported Zn [19] and Zn/Zr solid solutions [21] have been reported as the active component for CO2 activation, whilst MOR, MFI, BEA, etc. zeolites are applicable for aromatics conversion [22–24]. Aside from the studies focused on reaction mechanism and catalysts optimization, researchers also employed machine-learning to analyze the compositions and reaction conditions for better catalytic performance [25]. However, there are still several problems severely hindering the scale-up of ABCH reaction, which is (1) the low efficiency for batch reactor due to the sophisticated operation processes [25]; (2) the limited benzene/CO2 conversion stemming from low OVs concentrations and the incongruous synergism between zeolite and metal/metal oxide (conversion of CO2 to methanol is carried out under low temperatures but benzene alkylation is more favored at high temperatures) [26–28]; (3) the inevitable side products like ethylbenzene (EB) or C9+ aromatics caused by deeper alkylation or transformation of CO2 to other hydrocarbons [29]; (4) the unsatisfied catalytic lifetime brought by coking or poor hydrothermal stability [30–32]; (5) last but not least, the reaction network is still not clear. As a result, developing novel catalyst and establishing reaction network are rather meaningful to ABCH reaction. As summarized in previous report, activities for bifunctional catalysts in one-step CO2 conversion are mainly determined by the metal/metal oxide [33]. The spinel-structured catalysts feature various advantages when applied in CO2 utilization such as excellent thermostability, ease of synthesis, and abundant OVs compared to other counterparts [34,35]. Recently, spinel-based ZnGa2O4 are integrated with various zeolites like SAPO-34 and ZSM-5 for transforming CO2 into olefins and aromatics [36]. Zn/Ga oxides are also extensively used in CO2 photocatalysis and electro-catalysis ascribed to its high surface basicity and thermostability [37–39]. More importantly, spinel type oxide is capable of high-temperature methanol synthesis which grants it a chance to be coupled with zeolite for benzene alkylation reaction [40]. Therefore, Zn/Ga spinel would be a good candidate for ABCH reaction, via which the promotion in catalytic activities can be possibly achieved. Furthermore, selectivity and stabilities in such reactions are majorly dependent on zeolite components [41]. ZSM-5 zeolite, benefiting from its finely adjustable acidities and shape selectivity towards certain aromatics, has been widely used for benzene methylation and our former studies also confirm ZSM-5 is most suitable for such reactions [42]. However, studies about the effects of zeolites on ABCH reaction were seldom. EB, as one of the undesired products formed on zeolite acid sites, is hard to be separated from xylenes via conventional means economically [43] and there are some potential evolution routes such as (1) ethylation of benzene with ethene generated by CO2 to olefins or methanol to olefins reaction [44]; (2) xylene hydroisomerization [45]; (3) toluene side chain propagation [46]; and (4) ethylation of benzene with ethanol synthesized over metal/metal oxides [47]. Nevertheless, in ABCH reaction, ethene may easily be hydrogenated into ethane which is less possible to react with benzene for EB production [48–50]; and there are seemingly no active centers such as Lewis base for the toluene side-chain propagation or noble metal for xylene hydroisomerization. Thus, the origin of EB remains a mystery, the only conclusion is that, the formation of EB is mostly determined by the acidities of zeolites [51]. Yet, C9+ side products are believed to be formed on the external surface of HZSM-5 due to the large dynamic diameters (~7.3 Å) compared to those of HZSM-5 channels (5.1–5.6 Å) [52,53]. In consequence, both EB and C9+ can be adjusted by controlling the acidic properties of HZSM-5, but the effect of acidities has not been fully explored in ABCH reaction, as well as Zn/Ga oxides. In the present work, ABCH reaction was carried out using a bifunctional catalyst containing Zn/Ga oxides and HZSM-5 zeolites. To obtain an optimal catalyst, a series Zn/Ga oxides of different Zn/Ga ratios and HZSM-5 of different Si/Al ratios were studied, their structures and properties were systematically investigated via different characterizations. GC-MS, in-situ IR and catalytic evaluation were applied to study the reaction networks and mechanisms, especially for routes of EB evolution. These findings can provide a new method for developing effective and stable catalyst in the alkylation of benzene with CO2 and H2 and facilitate the understanding of the reaction networks. 2 Experimental 2.1 Source of reagents Zn(NO3)2 .6H2O, (NH4)2CO3 and benzene were all purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Ga(NO3)3·xH2O was provided by Shanghai Aladdin Bio-Chem Technology Co., Ltd. HZSM-5 (Si/Al = 13.5, 30, 100, 150, 200, 400) were all purchased from Nankai University Catalyst Plant. Mixed gas containing CO2, H2 and nitrogen (N2) were purchased from Air Liquide (China) Investment Co. LTD. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The Zn/Ga metal oxides with different Zn/Ga molar ratios were synthesized by a coprecipitation method. Typically, Ga(NO3)3·xH2O and Zn(NO3)2 .6H2O with a fixed molar ratio were dissolved into 100 mL deionized water. Then, a solution of (NH4)2CO3 was added dropwise into the mixed solution under magnetic agitation until the pH reached 8.0. The obtained white precipitate was aged for 24 h at 25 ºC. The solid product was recovered by filtration, followed by washing with deionized water and drying at 110 ºC for 12 h. After calcination in air at 450 ºC for 6 h, the obtained catalyst was denoted as ZnyGaOx, wherein y is the molar ratio of Zn/Ga. The tandem catalyst was prepared by a simple physical mixing method. The weight ratio of the Zn/Ga oxides and HZSM-5 zeolites with various Si/Al ratios was fixed at 1:1. After the mixture was pelleted into 20 − 40 mesh particles, the constituted catalyst containing Zn/Ga oxides and HZSM-5 will be named as ZnyGaOx/Z5(z), where z refers to the Si/Al ratio of HZSM-5. 2.3 Catalyst characterization X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected on a D8-Advance X-ray polycrystalline diffractometer. The diffraction angles were scanned from 5° to 80° (2θ) with a step size of 0.02°. Cu Kα radiation at 40 kV and 40 mA was used as the source of radiation. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained from a FEI Tecnai G2 F30 transmission electron microscope operating at 300 kV. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption was performed on Micrometrics 3Flex to detect specific surface properties and pore structures. Before the test, the sample was vacuumed to remove volatile organics and moisture at 350 ºC for 24 h. Then, the adsorption-desorption isotherms were measured at − 196 °C employing liquid nitrogen as coolant. The surface area was calculated from the adsorption branch in the range of p/p0 = 0.15–0.28 by Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method, total pore volume was estimated in terms of the relative pressure of 0.99. Inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometer (ICP-AES) was performed to determine the accurate proportion in ZnyGaOx catalysts. Analysis wavelength was 177–785 nm with an optical resolution of 0.009 nm and a focal distance of 400 mm. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried on a Thermo ESCALAB 250 instrument with monochromatic Al Kα radiation (1486.6 eV) as the X-ray source. The working voltage was 14 kV and the filament current was 30 mA. C1s binding energy centered at 284.8 eV was used as calibrations. The software XPSPEAK41 was used to analyze XPS original data. The Raman spectra were measured on an inVia Reflex instrument by exciting the samples with an argon ion laser at 325 nm and 785 nm, where the excitation source was a He-Cd laser. H2-Temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) measurements were performed on a VODO VDSorb-91i apparatus with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) in a H2-Ar mixture (5 vol% H2). Prior to reduction, the catalyst (100 mg) was pretreated in Ar flow at 200 ºC for 2 h, and then cooled down to 60 ºC. After that, H2-TPR experiment was started by raising the temperature to 500 ºC at a rate of 10 ºC/min. H2-temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) studies confirm that most Zn/Ga oxides can be fully reduced under 450 °C (Fig. S1). Temperature-programmed desorption of CO2 (CO2-TPD) was carried out in a quartz glass tube reactor on VODO VDSorb-91i. Initially, the catalyst was activated with 10 vol% H2 in Ar at 450 °C for 30 min and then cooled to 100 °C in flowing Ar followed by CO2 exposure (10 vol% CO2 in Ar). After CO2 saturation, the sample was flushed with Ar to remove weakly adsorbed and gas phase species. Finally, TPD was started by ramping the temperature with 10 ºC/min to 750 °C in Ar flow and TCD signal was recorded. NH3-Temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) was measured by a VODO VDSorb-91i instrument in a 10%NH3-He mixture. The sample was first ramped to 500 °C at 20 °C/min, in helium for 1 h, then cooled to room temperature. After which the sample was contacted with ammonia for 30 min. Prior to record, the sample was purged by helium at 150 °C to sweep the additional NH3. At last, TCD signal was recorded by rising the temperature to 700 ºC at a rate of 10 ºC/min. Infrared (IR) spectra of the pyridine adsorption were recorded on a Nicolet iS50 spectrometer, with 32 scans at an effective resolution of 4 cm−1. The wafer was mounted in a quartz IR cell equipped with a CaF2 window and a vacuum system. Before the pyridine adsorption, the samples were pretreated at 500 °C under vacuum, then cooled to 40 °C when pyridine vapor was introduced into the cell. The samples were heated in vacuum at 200 °C, 300 °C and 400 °C, respectively and spectra were recorded. To quantify the Lewis and Brønsted acid sites, the following Eqs. (1) and (2), reported by Emeis were used [54]: (1) C L = K L A 1450 = π IMEC L r 2 w A 1450 (2) C B = K L A 1540 = π IMEC B r 2 w A 1540 Herein, CL and CB correspond to the quantified concentrations of Lewis and Brønsted acid sites; A1450 and A1540 are the corrected integral areas of peaks at 1450 and 1540 cm−1 in the curve of FT-IR spectra; KL and KB are the molar extinction coefficients for Lewis and Brønsted acid sites; IMECL and IMECB equal 2.22 and 1.67 cm/μmol for Lewis and Brønsted acids, respectively; and w and r are the wafer weight and wafer radius of the disk. In-situ infra-red (in-situ IR) spectroscopy was performed on ThermoFisher Nicolet iS50 equipped with a mercury cadmium telluride (MCT) detector. Before the reactant was introduced into the reactor chamber, the catalyst was pre-reduced with hydrogen in 10%H2-Ar at 450 °C. The spectra were recorded in the range of 4000–1300 cm−1 by collecting 64 scans at a 4 cm−1 resolution. Gas chromatograph/Mass spectrometer (GC/MS) was carried on a PY/GC-MS/7890A-5975 C instrument to detect the organic matters from the catalysts after reaction. 2.4 Catalytic tests The ABCH reaction was performed in a high-pressure fixed-bed reactor with a 304 stainless-steel tube. Typically, 1.0 g catalyst with grain sizes of 20–40 meshes was loaded in the tube, and the rest of the tube was filled with quartz. The molar ratio of H2: CO2: C6H6 in the feed was designed to be 12:4:1, the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was 9000 mL·gcat −1·h−1, and the liquid hourly space velocity (LHSV) was 1.8 gC6H6·gcat −1·h−1. Before the reaction, the catalyst was pre-reduced with hydrogen at 450 ºC for 1 h. After reduction, the temperature was lowered to 425 °C; then, the reactant with a pressure of 3.0 MPa was introduced into the reactor to start the reaction. The gas phase was introduced into an online chromatograph produced by Shimadzu using a TDX-02 packed column (2 m) connected to a TCD detector and a PLOT-Q capillary column (30 m) connected to an FID detector. After cooled at room temperature through the cooling tank, the liquid products were analyzed using an offline gas chromatography equipped with an FID detector connected to a DB-WAX capillary column (30 m). CO2 efficiency = Feed benz Conv benz ( 1 × Select tol + 2 × Select xyl ) Feed CO 2 × Conv CO 2 . Feedbenz and FeedCO2 are the feed quantity of benzene and CO2, respectively. Feedbenz/FeedCO2 = 0.25. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterizations of Zn/Ga oxides Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of ZnO, Ga2O3 and Zn/Ga oxides with different mole ratios. Previous studies have proved that bi-valent and tri-valent metal oxides can easily form a spinel structure, namely AB2O4 type spinel. In this study, it can be unambiguously found out that Zn0.5GaOx possesses a typical spinel structure, presenting diffraction peaks at 18.4, 30.3, 35.7, 37.3, 43.4, 57.4 and 63.0° [36]. With the introduce of excessive zinc, peaks at 31.8, 34.4, 47.5, 68.0 and 69.0° standing for hexagonal ZnO began to emerge, as is the case for Zn3GaOx and Zn6GaOx. Pure Ga2O3 performs a γ-Ga2O3 type diffraction pattern due to the low calcination temperature (450 ℃), displaying two weak peaks at 36.2° and 64.1° denoting to (311) and (440) planes of γ-Ga2O3, respectively [55–57], Zn0.35GaOx also shows a combination pattern of γ-Ga2O3 and Zn/Ga spinel. XRD results confirm that spinel structure can be formed within Zn/Ga ratios of 0.5–0.75, more Zn content will result in the formation of isolated ZnO phase and less Zn content causes the existence of γ-Ga2O3. To describe the effects of Zn content on the morphologies of Ga2O3 or Zn/Ga spinel, it is better to employ transmission electron microscopy (TEM) experiments owning to the small sizes of those metal oxides. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of ZnO, Zn1.5GaOx, Zn0.75GaOx and Ga2O3 oxides are shown in Fig. S2, it can be seen that the particle size of pure ZnO is around 26 nm, while the pure Ga2O3 is mainly composed of tiny particles with diameters less than 8 nm. With a spinel structure, the nanocrystal size of Zn0.75GaOx particles is in the range of 4–12 nm, peaking at 7–9 nm, and no other obvious morphologies can be disclosed. However, with too much Zn introduced into Ga2O3, like Zn1.5GaOx oxide, the catalyst has a typical characteristic including ZnO and Zn/Ga spinel phase, which is in line with the XRD results. Accordingly, the proper addition of Zn into Ga2O3 or Zn/Ga spinel did not exert significant changes on their morphologies as those Zn mainly replaces the positions of Ga rather than forming new phases. The textural properties of Zn/Ga oxides are shown in Table 1. ZnO sample owns a relatively smaller specific surface area (39 m2·g−1) and larger pore diameter (33.9 nm) compared to the Zn/Ga counterparts. Meanwhile Ga2O3 possesses a rather small pore diameter (6.2 nm) but a comparable specific surface with Zn/Ga oxides. For Zn/Ga oxides, Zn0.5GaOx exhibits a maximum specific surface area of 157 m2·g−1 attributing to the mesoporous nature of ZnGa2O4 spinel [58], and the specific surface decreases gradually with the rising Zn/Ga ratios. Moreover, from sample Zn0.5GaOx to Zn1.5GaOx, the changes in total pore volume are not obvious, fluctuating around 0.6 cm3·g−1. Generally, no big differences have been detected for the Zn/Ga oxides, except for pure ZnO and Ga2O3. XPS and ICP-AES are employed to analysis the compositions and elemental distributions of each sample. As listed in Table 1, it’s very interesting that the superficial Zn/Ga ratios are generally higher than those of the bulk, implying that excess zinc tends to be enriched on the surface. Meanwhile, the bulk compositions are nearly identical to the feed ratios, which predicates a sufficient precipitating process during the preparation. In order to provide more information for the as-synthesized metal oxides, Raman spectroscopy ( Fig. 2) was used to characterize the phase structure. For spectrum obtained via 325 nm beam, peaks of 1LO (570 cm−1) and 2LO phonon (1140 cm−1) are found, which are the characteristics of ZnO phase [59]. With the increasing Ga addition, two shoulders at 605 cm−1 and 710 cm−1 representing the T2 g and A1 g vibration modes of ZnGa2O4 spinel structure respectively are gradually heightened, illustrating the formation of ZnGa2O4 on the surface [60]. However, the vibration modes of Ga2O3 are absent in Fig. 2a, which is believed to be caused by the Zn-rich surface and lack of enough Ga species. Since the wavelength of Raman laser determined the detectable thickness, 785 nm beam was also used to provide more information about the bulk. As can be seen in Fig. 2b, the Ga2O3 Ag/Bg vibration peak (665 cm−1) is observed in Zn0.35GaOx, indicating the existence of isolated Ga2O3 species in the interior due to less Zn content in the bulk [11]. With the increasing Zn addition, the T2 g (610 cm−1) and A1 g (713 cm−1) vibration modes of ZnGa2O4 spinel structure gradually disappeared instead by a series of weak signals at 500 ~ 800 cm−1 while the characteristic signals of ZnO including E2(high)-E2(low) and E2(high) located at 332 and 438 cm−1 gradually emerged [61]. The vanishing of obvious Raman peaks is related with the disruption from lattice defects or distortions generated by the low calcination temperatures or non-stoichiometric Zn/Ga ratios [62]. Besides, the peaks of ZnO vibration modes in Zn/Ga oxides are not obvious anymore compared with those detected in 325 nm, proving that ZnO are less prone to be in the bulk. In consistent with the results from N2 adsorption and surface elemental composition, it is certain that the excess zinc tends to appear at the surface of the Zn/Ga oxides. Thus, it can be concluded from Raman spectra that the Zn/Ga spinel metal oxides are highly disordered in the bulk due to low calcination temperature or excess zinc, but the surface was more regular and enriched by ZnO species. Furthermore, concerning the weak XRD signals denoting to ZnO phase in Zn1GaOx and Zn0.75GaOx in contrast to the large quantity of excess zinc, it can be inferred that the excess ZnO species are mainly in amorphous state covering the surface of Zn/Ga oxides. XPS measurements are utilized to analyze the electron structure of Zn/Ga oxides. As shown in Fig. 3a, two peaks at 1044.7 eV and 1021.6 eV are attributed to Zn 2p1/2 and 2p3/2 spin-orbit split peaks in the near-edge originating from ZnO or Zn/Ga oxides [63,64]. There is no obvious difference in Zn 2p peaks between each Zn/Ga oxide, suggesting an identical electron nature for Zn species. Fig. 3b shows the XPS spectra of Ga. Generally, the Ga 3d orbital spectrum can be further deconvoluted into two independent peaks at 20.7 and 20.2 eV standing for Ga 3d3/2 and Ga 3d5/2, and no obvious differences can be distinguished for peaks locating at those positions. However, due to the inevitable formation of OVs at the surface, which possibly stems from the defects or distortions as evidenced by Raman spectra [13], an additional peak at lower binding energies (19.2 eV) is also needed to be fitted into the curve [65,66], and OVs can be quantitatively described using the following equation: OVs concentrations = [Svacancies/(Svacancies+SGa 3d3/2 +SGa 3d5/2)]. As listed in Fig. 3b, the Zn/Ga oxides show different contents of OVs with various Zn/Ga ratios. Zn0.75GaOx owns the most OVs (34.9%) and this value drops significantly with more or less zinc, suggesting the moderate introduction of excess zinc leads to more defects on the surface. In addition, a small and broad mound at ~22.6 eV is also observable due to the contribution from the oxygen 2 s [67]. Fig. 3c shows the O 1 s XPS spectra. For analysis, three peaks named as O1, O2 and O3 are fitted into the O 1 s curve. O1 is attributed to the lattice oxygen of ZnO (530.2 eV), ZnGa2O4 (530.4 eV) and Ga2O3 (530.8 eV), which occupies the majority of surface oxygen [60]. As reported previously, O2 at 531.4 eV and O3 at 532.7 eV are regarded to result from oxygen vacancies and chemisorbed oxygen, respectively [68,69]. For pure ZnO and Ga2O3, O2 only makes up ca. 19% due to the limited surface defects. On the other side, O2 in Zn/Ga oxides is more distinguishable, this value increases with the addition of more Zn firstly, reaching its maximum (37.6%) in Zn0.75GaOx, and then drops to 30.3% in Zn1Ga. Notably, the overall changes in O1s binding energies are in opposite with those in Ga 3d, which ensures an electron transfer phenomenon from oxygen to gallium. The XPS results confirm that Zn0.75GaOx possesses the most OVs, which is consistent with the conclusion from Ga XPS. Combined with Raman, XRD, N2-adsorption results, it can be concluded that the defects or distortions within bulk spinel structures may play a pivot role in holding more non-stoichiometric ZnO as amorphous phases in the surfaces, meanwhile the excess zinc leads to the creation of abundant OVs originating from the massive defects existing in the amorphous ZnO species. The CO2-TPD is widely used to measure the surface basicity of catalysts [70]. As depicted in Fig. 4, peaks centering at ~160 ℃ can be assigned to CO2 desorption on weak basic sites interpreted as surface M-OH groups, while those shoulders at ~250 ℃ partially overlapped with the low-temperature peaks are caused by the CO2 adsorbed on metal-oxygen pairs [71], both of the two sites are strongly determined by the contents of OVs [72]. Though quantitative analysis of the two peaks in one curve is difficult owing the severe overlap, CO2-TPD performed with Zn0.75GaOx and Zn0.5GaOx clearly displayed better CO2 adsorption abilities, which is 4.98 and 3.84 μmol/g respectively as referred to pure metal oxides (less than 1 μmol/g) or other Zn/Ga oxides (less than 3 μmol/g). Concerning the above conclusions, it can be inferred that more lattice defects and amorphous ZnO species can be generated by adjusting the Zn/Ga ratios, providing more OVs as adsorption sites for CO2. Zn0.75GaOx possesses most abundant OVs and the best ability for CO2 adsorption. 3.2 Characterizations of zeolites Fig. S3 shows the XRD results of zeolite samples. All zeolites exhibit typical MFI structures (PDF#44–0003), displaying diffraction peaks at 2θ = 8°~10° and 20°~25 °. The comparable heights and widths of these XRD patterns suggest comparable crystallinities and particle sizes, without obvious changes. The texture properties are studied via nitrogen adsorption-desorption. As shown in Table S2, there is no clear difference in the BET specific surface between HZSM-5 zeolites. Meanwhile, the pore volumes and total pore volumes are also very close, which fluctuates around 3.0 nm and 0.25 cm3·g−1, respectively. Fig. S4 shows the NH3-TPD profiles, which is employed to identify the strength and density of acidity in ZSM-5. As can be seen from Fig. S4, the total acidity is typically determined as weak acidic sites (<350 °C) and strong acidic sites (>350 °C) [6] according to the desorption temperatures. Generally, the acid density decreases gradually with the rise of Si/Al ratio (SAR). Consequently, for Z5(13.5) and Z5(30), the acid density is clearly higher than others, which is 0.565 mmol/g and 0.352 mmol/g, respectively, due to the higher contents of compensating protons brought by lower SARs. Then the acid density drops to 0.024 mmol/g linearly in Z5(400). Besides, the proportion of strong acid sites locating at ~430 °C disappears in Z5(100), substituted by a peak centering at ~330 °C for ZSM-5 with SARs higher than 100 and this peak moves towards even lower temperatures with increasing SARs gradually. This means acid density decreases with the growth of SAR, and the strong acid sites was shifted into medium-strong acid sties for Z5 possessing higher Si/Al ratios. Aside from the density and strength of ZSM-5, py-IR is employed to distinguish the types of acidities, which is Brønsted or Lewis acidic sites. IR spectra after adsorption and desorption of pyridine is recorded as shown in Fig. S5. The band at 1540 cm−1 corresponds to the stretch of N-H bond of pronated pyridinium adsorbed on Brønsted acid sites while the band at 1450 cm−1 is related to the stretch of C-N bond of pyridine adsorbed on Lewis acid sites. It can be seen that Brønsted acid sites decreases obviously with increasing SARs, yet, no obvious changes have been detected for Lewis acid sites (Fig. S4). Combined with NH3-TPD results, it can be seen that ZSM-5 zeolites of various Si/Al ratios mainly differ in acidities, higher SAR zeolites exhibit lower Brønsted acid density and weaker Brønsted acid strength. 3.3 Catalytic performance 3.3.1 Effects of metal oxides Figs. 5 and 6 present the catalytic performances of bifunctional catalysts. The pure metal oxide constituted bifunctional catalysts, denoted as ZnO/Z5(30) and Ga2O3/Z5(30), are less active than the Zn/Ga oxides counterparts, displaying benzene conversions of 20.5% and 21.3% respectively. While benzene conversion rises to 27.5% for Zn0.35GaOx/Z5(30) and continuously increases with Zn/Ga ratios, achieving the vertex value (36.1%) for Zn0.75GaOx/Z5(30), then it reduces to 21.3% consecutively for Zn6GaOx/Z5(30). As to selectivity, toluene, xylene, EB and C9+ make up most of the products. With more Zn content, the xylene selectivity increases from 6.4% for Ga2O3/Z5(30) to 19.0% for Zn0.75GaOx/Z5(30) and then decreases gradually to 6.4% for ZnO/Z5(30), nevertheless, toluene selectivity displays a reverse changing trend compared to xylene, varying from 71.0% to 84.3% parallelly. This is ascribed to the methylation reaction of toluene into xylenes, the degree of which was enhanced by the catalytic activity. Three xylene isomers displayed an equilibrium composition, which is ortho-xylene: meta-xylene: para-xylene ≈ 1:2:1 pertaining to the isomerization reaction on exterior acid sites [73]. As the main side products, EB and C9+ ranges from 4.0% to 8.3% in all samples, the origin of EB will be discussed in the following while C9+ is proposed to be produced on acid sites of the ZSM-5 external surface due to the large molecular size (0.51–0.56 nm for ZSM-5 and 0.73 nm for C9+) [52]. All samples have a high phenyl ring utilization (95%), demonstrating the suppression of ring-open reactions via over-hydrogenation of benzene. In the gaseous phase, CO2 conversions and utilizations varies simultaneously with that of benzene conversions. Zn0.75GaOx/Z5(30) shows the highest CO2 conversion (30.1%) and CO2 efficiency (32.7%). Generally, as the main gaseous side product, CO makes up about 70% of the total gaseous products for most catalysts [36], which is caused by reverse-water-gas-shift reaction (RWGS) [74]. Other gaseous side products such as C1~C5 light hydrocarbons are all very scarce, with total selectivity of less than 3%. From the above discussions, it is concluded that Zn/Ga oxides differ a little in texture properties and a lot in surface structures, which may impact the catalytic performances. It should be emphasized that, the texture properties such as specific surface of metal oxides only exert negligible influences according to our previous study [12] and the specific surface area actually varies not much for most Zn/Ga oxides, thus, the differences in activities and selectivity can be safely attributed to surface structures, which determines the catalytic performances mainly via OVs [13]. To reveal the structure-performance relationship of Zn/Ga oxides, correlation between surface O2 content (in all elements), as the descriptor of OVs, and reaction activities is shown in Fig. 7. As a whole, more surface O2 leads to higher benzene/CO2 conversion and CO2 efficiency. Zn0.75GaOx, containing the most OVs as much as 21.6%, exhibits the highest benzene conversion, CO2 conversion and CO2 efficiency. A notable feature is that a linear relationship between surface O2 content and conversions or CO2 efficiencies is approximately correlated, which further proves that the OVs is the main factor deciding the catalytic performances. 3.3.2 Effects of SARs of HZSM-5 Fig. 8 shows benzene conversions and compositions of liquid state products using the combination of Zn0.75GaOx and zeolites with different SARs. It can be seen that the activities present a volcano shaped curve with increasing SARs, which climbs from 34.8% for Zn0.75GaOx/Z5(13.5) to the summit value of 39.1% in Zn0.75GaOx/Z5(100), implying ABCH reaction needs suitable acidic properties. Further increase the SAR is unbeneficial to benzene conversions, which is possibly caused by the reduction in total acidities as evidenced in NH3-TPD and py-IR. The toluene and xylene selectivity changes with benzene conversions analogically to the results in Fig. 5, which is the higher benzene conversion, the higher xylene selectivity and lower toluene selectivity. However, unlike the similar total selectivity towards EB and C9+ obtained using various Zn/Ga oxides, total EB and C9+ selectivity drops obviously with higher SARs. Concerning the close texture properties of all ZSM-5 zeolites, this can be attributed to the reduction in both total and surface acidities, which will be discussed in the following. Meanwhile, combined with different ZSM-5, the catalysts present similar CO2 conversions of ~30% ( Fig. 9) since CO2 is activated on same Zn/Ga oxides. The Zn0.75GaOx/Z5(100) exhibits highest CO2 efficiency and lowest CO selectivity, indicating the CO2 to methanol has been promoted forwardly and ABCH reaction need a moderate acid strength. It should be emphasized that, acid sites have been proved to be responsible for the alkylation reaction, and one may consider that higher acid density should be favored to achieve better activities. But the activity and selectivity of Zn0.75GaOx/Z5(13.5) became even worse with respect to those of Zn0.75GaOx/Z5(100). It is speculated that higher acid densities and strengths are also more prone to result in coke, which further leads to the blockage of zeolite channels and coverage of acid sites, hence the lower SAR zeolites do not always outperform higher ones [75,76]. To analyze the relationship between zeolite acid density and carbon deposition, the fresh and spent catalysts after 8 h of reaction were characterized by nitrogen adsorption, as shown in Table S1. It can be easily found out that there are reductions in all texture parameters for each sample, but the catalysts composed of higher SAR zeolites demonstrated less changes. For example, the specific surface of fresh Zn0.75GaOx/Z5(13.5) is 182 m2/g and it declined sharply to 59 m2/g after reaction, while the two values of Zn0.75GaOx/Z5(100) are 189 m2/g and 118 m2/g, respectively, as is the case for other properties like pore volume, etc. In consequence, the unsatisfied reactivity of low SAR zeolites can be explained by blockage of channels or coverage of acid sites resulting from coke depositions. Concerning the py-IR and NH3-TPD results, it is also illustrated that medium-strong Brønsted acid sites, proper Brønsted acid density and a certain number of Lewis acid sites are beneficial to ABCH reaction. 3.3.3 Stability tests Catalyst stability is crucial to the potential industrial applications, which is shown in Fig. 10. After 80 h of reaction at 425 °C, the conversion of benzene and CO2 are sustained at 39% and 30%, respectively, indicating that Zn0.75GaOx/Z5(100) catalyst is highly stable. 3.4 Investigation of reaction networks Even though several works haven been carried out on the ABCH reaction, the networks and transformation relationship between each chemical is still unclear. To reveal the reaction network of ABCH reaction, formation mechanism of EB was firstly studied. As mentioned in the introduction, one possible route for the existence of EB is the ethylation of benzene with ethylene, wherein ethylene is postulated to be formed by methanol to olefins (MTO) reaction via aromatic pool circulation mechanism ( Scheme 1) [77]. However, in the ABCH reaction, the selectivity towards ethylene and ethane occupies less than 0.5% in all gaseous products, corresponding to a concentration less than 100 ppm (Figs. 6 and 9). Besides, the C2 species formed on metal oxide is also very limit, which is 0.2% on single Zn/Ga oxides feeding CO2/H2 solely (Table S3). Such low content is hardly to guarantee the successful formation of enough EB, especially for the value of 9.3% EB selectivity in Zn0.75GaOx/Z5(13.5) (Fig. 8). To assess the possibility of the ethylene route, the species entrapped inside the zeolite are analyzed. The catalysts by introducing CO2/H2 or CO2/H2/benzene as reactants for 8 h were collected and dissolved in HF 5% solution, then the organic compounds were extracted by CH2Cl2 for GC-MS analysis. As illustrated in Fig. 11, these organics are mostly benzene, followed by toluene/xylene, and a few polymethylbenzenes when CO2/H2 is utilized as reactants. Since polymethylbenzenes such as 1,3,5-TriMB, 1,2,4-TriMB, and 1,2,4,5-TetraMB belong to important intermediates in the aromatic pool circulation process [78], the successful establishment of aromatics pool can be inferred. On the contrary, with the interference of benzene, polymethylbenzenes are absent in the spectrum, demonstrating a disturbance effect of aromatic pool species from benzene. It is believed the transalkylation between polymethylbenzenes and benzene is responsible for this phenomenon, due to the feasibility of this reaction on Bronsted acid sites of ZSM-5 [79]. The failure in the observation of aromatic pool intermediates under reaction conditions substantiates that ethylene are difficult to be produced via MTO routes in ABCH process, along with the low ethylene content, it seems unreasonable to attribute the formation of EB to the ethylation of benzene with C2 species. On the other hand, it is also interesting to note that there is ethanol retained in zeolite, which may be the source of ethyl group for EB generation. Besides, the detection of diethylbenzene as shown in Fig. 11, which may come from the deeper ethylation of benzene, also corroborates this hypothesis. To acquire more evidence for the ethanol routes, in-situ IR is carried out over Zn0.75GaOx/Z5(100) catalyst at 425 °C under 0.6 MPa ( Fig. 12). When CO2 and H2 were fed into Zn0.75GaOx/Z5(100) catalyst (Fig. 12a1;a2), characteristic peaks of methoxy (2957, 2857 and 1463 cm−1), formate (1639 cm−1) and ethoxy (2962 and 2927 cm−1) were recorded [19,80]. Meanwhile, it can be seen that IR peaks representing the ν(C-H) mode of methyl on toluene (3018 and 2987 cm−1), the ν(C-H) mode of benzene (2000–1800 and 1500–1400 cm−1), and the C-C stretching vibrations of phenol ring (1564 and 1528 cm−1) also appeared, which is in agreement with the results from GC-MS chromatogram [6,12,19]. Then the in-situ cell was swept by benzene saturated argon (Fig. 12b1;b2), it has been found that the peaks standing for methoxy and ethoxy were consumed rapidly, as they were reacted by benzene to produce toluene and EB, which is further confirmed by catalytic evaluation. The in-situ IR results confirms the formation of ethanol over Zn/Ga oxides and the existence of benzene ethylation reaction over Zn/Ga-Z5 bifunctional catalysts, both of the two reactions have also been reported elsewhere at similar reaction conditions [80–82]. Another feature of EB is that its selectivity increases rapidly with the decrease of Si/Al ratios, suggesting the acidity-dependent generation of EB. Table 2 compares the ethylation of benzene with ethanol over Zn0.75GaOx/Z5(13.5) and Zn0.75GaOx/Z5(200), as can be seen, the benzene conversion of Z5(13.5) is 61.6%, obviously higher than 48.7% of Z5(200) while the ethanol conversions are all 100% for the two catalysts. This trend is in consistent with the above findings, which proves zeolite with higher Bronsted acid densities are more efficient in catalyzing the conversion of benzene with ethanol, offering another evidence for the ethanol route of EB formation. In the same time, high SAR ZSM-5 zeolites also possess less surface acid sites as active centers for C9+ production, thus the selectivity of C9+ was also suppressed by employing high SAR zeolites. However, there is still several other potential ways to produce EB, namely the side-chain propagation of toluene, toluene disproportionation into EB and xylene isomerization into EB. To testify the chances for the occurrence of the three reactions, catalytic evaluations utilizing diverse reactant are carried out under same reaction conditions as ABCH. It can be seen in Tables S4, S5 and S6 that, the above-mentioned three reactions can rarely take place, thus the formation of EB can be safely attributed to the ethylation of benzene with ethanol. Overall, by changing the Zn/Ga ratios, more defects in the bulk of spinel structures can be created, inducing the formation of amorphous ZnO on the surface. Through the adjustment, OVs as the main active center for methanol and ethanol synthesis can be enhanced. Zn0.75GaOx owning the most OVs shows the best activity due to the proper excess Zn level. Then the two intermediates diffuse onto the acid sites to react with benzene, where aromatics transformation cycle is formed. In this cycle, xylene isomerization into EB, toluene side-chain propagation and toluene disproportionation into EB are reactions difficult to occur, meanwhile, transalkylation reaction between benzene and multimethylbenzenes, isomerization of para-, meta-, and ortho- xylenes, and further alkylation of aromatics can easily take place [78]. It should be noticed that MTO reaction is suppressed pertaining to the transalkylation reactions of multimethylbenzenes with benzene. As these reactions related to aromatics are all carried out over the acid sites of ZSM-5, the acidic properties determines their degrees and priorities, higher acid densities favors the ethylation of benzene with ethanol and deep alkylation reaction, leading to unsatisfied toluene/xylene selectivity and even coking, while too lower acid densities and strengths are beneficial to the methylation reaction showing better toluene/xylene selectivity but limited activities concerning the shortage of active sites. Z5(100) possesses a moderate acid strength and density, presenting the best activity and excellent selectivity. On the ground of the findings in this work, a reaction network has been put up with as shown in Scheme 2. 4 Conclusions A bifunctional catalyst comprising adjustable zinc and gallium oxides (Zn/Ga oxides) and HZSM-5 zeolites is developed for the alkylation of benzene with CO2 and H2 (ABCH reaction). Among the Zn/Ga oxides, Zn0.75GaOx with a spinel structure has the best performance for ABCH reaction as a result of abundant OVs, suitable specific surface area and the best ability for CO2 adsorption. A series of HZSM-5 zeolites with different Si/Al ratio are used to explore the influence of acidity on reaction. Zn0.75GaOx/Z5(100) is proved to be the most active catalyst with high benzene conversion (39.1%) and total selectivity of toluene and xylene (92.7%), indicating that bifunctional catalyst also needs proper Brønsted acid density and a certain number of Lewis acid sites. The reaction networks study suggests that methanol and ethanol are both intermediates and EB is generated by alkylation of benzene with ethanol. Other EB generation routes are difficult to occur due to their harsh reaction conditions. Finally, we propose an ABCH reaction network containing BTX transformation cycle and hydrocarbon pool transformation cycle. Contrary to the alkylation reaction of benzene with methanol, MTO reaction is suppressed pertaining to the transalkylation reactions of multimethylbenzenes with benzene in ABCH reaction. Our present work provides a new method for developing effective and stable catalyst in the transformation of CO2 into high value-added chemicals, and facilitate the understanding of the reaction networks and EB generation mechanism. coredata.dc:description: Alkylation of benzene with carbon dioxide (CO2) is significant for converting greenhouse gas and surplus benzene into value-added toluene and xylene. Herein, a bifunctional catalyst comprising Zn/Ga oxides and HZSM-5 zeolite was developed to efficiently promote the methylation of benzene with CO2 and H2. This catalytic system exhibited excellent performance at 425 ℃ and 3.0 MPa, through which benzene conversion of 39.1% and total xylene/toluene selectivity of 92.7% have been achieved. Furthermore, the catalysts are carefully characterized; compositions of Zn/Ga oxides and Si/Al ratios of HZSM-5 zeolite are recognized as decisive factors for reaction activity and selectivity respectively. Additionally, primary reaction pathways are explored and testified to provide detailed understanding for the establishment of reaction networks, especially for mechanisms of ethylbenzene evolution. These findings are able to provide more deep insights into the process of benzene alkylation, which further facilitates the emergence of effective catalysts with potential industrial applications.
coredata.dc:title: Examination of key factors determining the catalytic performance of Zn-Ga/HZSM-5 bifunctional catalysts and establishment of reaction network in alkylation of benzene with carbon dioxide
